families.name: Kings of Leon
history: The kings of Leon that we studied have origin with Ordoño son of Alfonso III, 'o magno'

people.name: Ramiro (+951)
history: Ramiro is Ordoño's son as informed in 'Crônica de Sampiro' (Santos, Francisco C., 1921, pp. 53; Medieval Lands, 2019), but his mother cannot be confirmed due to a document dated 02/21/897 (Herculano, Alexandre, 1868, Diplomata et Chartae, Volumen I, Fascicvlvs I, pp. 7. ; Medieval Lands, 2019). When his government began he was named Ramiro II (Medieval Lands, 2019)

Ramiro II had children in two different marriages and also a hypotetical relationship: the 'códice Roda'names explicitly Urraca (Lacarra, José M., 1945, pp. 236,238; Medieval Lands, 2019), but it does not name Adosinda (Lacarra, José M., 1945, pp. 238; Medieval Lands, 2019) wives of Ramiro, on the other hand, Adosinda is cited in another source that I did not have access (Medieval Lands, 2019). His hypothetical relationship with Artiga was reported 3 centuries after his life by "Livro Velho de Linhagens" authors (Herculano, Alexandre, Scriptores, 1860, pp. 180-181).

marriages.name: Artiga
history: The description of this person's life is known as the legend of Gaia, because this is the place where events supposed happened (Herculano, Alexandre, Scriptores, 1860, pp. 180-181; Rei, António, 2013, pp.21-36).

Distinct research were published t investigate what was described by the author of "Livro Velho" and followed for other nobiliarchy: António Rei suggests that her real name was 'Arîqa' (Rei, António, 2013, pp. 11-12) and she really married Ramiro II (Rei, António, 2013, pp. 15). Years before Francisco Dória published a text available on site geneall (Geneall, 2001), his work has the same Antonio Rei's logic connecting her to the prophet Muhammad, but during forum discussion he diverges citing that she married with Lovesendes instead king Ramiro II.

children.name: Lovesendo Ramires
history: There is not any document or chronicle that proofs this person was real, but it is possible to find arguments that the person could be real (Rei, António, 2013, pp. 11; Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 208).

people.name: Lovesendo Ramires
history: There is not any document or chronicle that confirms the person's existence, but it is possible to arrive at the conclusion that could be real (Rei, António, 2013, pp. 11; Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 208).

marriages.name: Sa'd
history: Hypothetical marriage suggested by António Rei (Rei, António, 2013, pp. 11,15).

marriages.name: Artiga
history: Francisco Dória suggested this marriage (Geneall, 2001) instead to marriage Ramiro II

children.name: Aboazar Lovesendes
history: There is no document or chronicle that connects him to his father, it is possible to arrive to the conclusion that the person should exist, because his hypothetical son was named Aboazar Lovesendes and his first grandson was named Lovesendo (Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 208).
